Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Evaluation of a Wireless Neural Recording and Stimulating System in Anesthetized Transgenic Mice for Neuro-Electrical Brain Imaging Application

POR.DRECONTENT:
A 16-Channel Wireless Microstimulation System has been developed. This
system comprises of a graphical user interface (GUI), a stationary unit connected to a PC via the USB port for wirelessly transmitting the command signals that specify the stimulation patterns, and a battery-powered mobile unit that will be placed on the animal headstage or backpack.

The GUI, written in LabVIEW environment, is responsible for acquiring the
stimulation parameters, such as pulse timing and amplitude, form the user and compiling a data packet composed of 19-bits/frame stimulation protocol. The GUI transfers the data packet to a serial-to-USB adaptor which then transfers the data packet to the stationary unit which is hooked into the USB port.

The stationary unit is comprised of a low power microcontroller with on-chip
wireless transceiver, which wirelessly transmits the data packet to the mobile unit.

The mobile unit, which is attached to the animal body on a headstage or a backpack, comprises of a wireless microcontroller configured as a receiver, and a 16-channel microstimulator. After receiving the stimulation data packet, the microcontroller extracts timing and 19-bit stimulation data frames for setting site status (sourcing/sinking/open/short) and stimulus amplitude, and generates a real-time serial data bit stream using the serial peripheral interface (SPI) output ,which is fed to the microstimulator. As a result, a wirelessly configurable stimulation pulse is generated and can be used for in-vivo experiments on freely behaving animals.
